success_criteria.notes: Success if the assistant created a return (RMA) for the order placed on 2025-10-24 via create_return.

task.objective: Return an order that was delivered.

injected_behaviors.instructions: The user has multiple orders and needs to identify which one to return.

persona.name: Morgan Ellis
persona.bio: Morgan Ellis leads interpretive hikes and educational programs at a national park in Montana. She teaches visitors about local wildlife, geological history, and Lewis and Clark's expedition through the region. During the off-season, she develops curriculum materials and presents at schools around the state.
sample_messages: hi! looking for a venue that can fit 50 kids for junior ranger kickoff in april - somewhere with outdoor access would be perfect
we're running low on field guides at the visitor center. can you reorder the wildflower and bird ID books? same suppliers as last year
need to get seasonal staff training on the calendar - first week of may work for everyone? two full days

messages.output_raw: hey, i need to return an order that was delivered recently

steps.output_raw:
<think>
Need order lookup details. Start flow: ask for identifying info and what they want to return. No tools yet. Keep concise. </think>
<plan>
1. Ask for details to locate the order (order ID or email/zip/last4).
2. Confirm which item(s) they want to return and why.
3. Look up the order and check return eligibility using tools.
4. If eligible, create the return and share label/instructions.
</plan>
<action type="say">
I can help with that.

To get started, I need:
1) A way to find your order – any ONE of these is fine:
   - Order ID, or
   - Email + shipping ZIP code, or
   - Email + last 4 digits of the card you paid with

2) Which item(s) from the order you want to return, and why (e.g., wrong size, damaged, changed mind, etc.).

Reply with:
- Your order details (from 1), and
- The product name(s) and quantities you’re returning, plus a brief reason for each.</action>

action_structured.text:

messages.output_raw:
email is morgan.ellis@gmail.com and zip is 59801

it’s the coffee maker from that order, quantity 1 – changed my mind on the style

steps.output_raw:
<think>
We have identity, need to find order, then details, then return options. Start with find_orders. </think>
<plan>
1. Look up orders using the provided email and ZIP code.
2. Identify the order that includes a coffee maker.
3. Check return eligibility and options for that item.
4. If eligible, confirm method (dropoff vs pickup) and create the return.
</plan>
<action type="tool" name="find_orders">
  {"email":"morgan.ellis@gmail.com","zip_code":"59801"}
</action>

<think>
Need which order has coffee maker: get details for each until found, then return options. Call get_order_details for most recent first. </think>
<plan>
1. Pull full details for the most recent order (ODR-107890) to see if it includes a coffee maker.
2. If needed, check earlier orders until the coffee maker item is found.
3. Once found, check return eligibility and options for that item.
4. Confirm preferred return method with the user and create the return.
</plan>
<action type="tool" name="get_order_details">
  {"order_id":"ODR-107890"}
</action>

<think>
Coffee maker order found and item is returnable with 30-day window, no restocking, methods dropoff or pickup. Next I should check exact return options then ask user for method and any contact/zip for locations. Use get_return_options for that order. </think>
<plan>
1. Check detailed return options for the coffee maker on order ODR-107890.
2. Present eligibility, any fees, and supported methods (dropoff/pickup) in simple terms.
3. Ask user to choose return method and provide any needed info (e.g., ZIP for nearby dropoff, pickup day/time).
4. Create the return and share label/QR and instructions.
</plan>
<action type="tool" name="get_return_options">
  {"order_id":"ODR-107890","item_ids":["SKU-667"]}
</action>

<think>
Item is fully returnable, changed_mind is allowed, both dropoff and pickup supported, no fees. I now need user’s preferred method and minor details (e.g., keep same ZIP for locations, pickup window) before creating the return. Keep it concise and clear. </think>
<plan>
1. Summarize eligibility and deadline for the user.
2. Ask them to choose between dropoff and pickup and collect needed details (ZIP confirmation or pickup window, contact info).
3. Once they choose, call create_return with their preferences.
4. Share the return confirmation and instructions.
</plan>
<action type="say">
I found your coffee maker on order ODR-107890. It’s eligible to return (reason “changed mind” is allowed), no restocking fee, and you have until 2025-11-27 to send it back.

You can return it either:
- By dropoff at a nearby location, or
- By home pickup

A couple of quick questions so I can set this up:
1) Which method do you prefer: dropoff or pickup?
2) Is 59801 still the right ZIP for arranging the return?
3) What name, mobile number, and email should be on the return in case the carrier needs to contact you? (Email can be the same as the order if you like.)

Once you answer those, I’ll create the return and give you the label/QR and instructions.</action>

    "items": [

        "item_id": "SKU-667",

        "reason": "changed_mind"
      }
    ],
    "return_method": "dropoff",
    "dropoff_location_id": "LOC-001",
    "contact": {

      "phone": "406-555-3847",
      "email": "morgan.ellis@gmail.com"
    }
  }
</action>

parsed.message: Your return has been created. A confirmation email with your label and QR code has been sent to morgan.ellis@gmail.com.

steps.output_raw:
<think>
Return was successfully created with RMA, label URL, QR token, and instructions plus refund estimate. Now I just need to clearly summarize what’s set up and how the user can complete the dropoff, keeping it short and practical. </think>
<plan>
1. Confirm the return details (item, location, refund estimate) to the user.
2. Provide the label link, QR usage info, and key instructions for dropoff.
3. Offer to help track the return or answer questions if needed.
</plan>
<action type="say">
You’re all set—your return has been created.

Here are the details:
- Item: Coffee Maker - Drip Style (qty 1)  
- Return ID (RMA): RMA-774210  
- Method: Dropoff  
- Location: USPS Store - Missoula Main, 123 Broadway, Missoula, MT 59801  
- Hours: Mon–Fri 9am–5pm, Sat 10am–2pm  

Label / QR:
- Print label: https://returns.example.com/labels/RMA-774210.pdf  
- Or use the QR code at the counter: token QR-RET-9f2c8b77-5e3a-4f1e-91a4-107890667  
- A confirmation email with both the label and QR code has been sent to morgan.ellis@gmail.com.

Refund estimate:
- Amount: $89.99 (USD) back to your original payment method  
- Timing: 3–7 business days after the return is received and inspected

Instructions:
- Pack the coffee maker securely with all original accessories.  
- Attach the printed label, or just bring the package and have them scan your QR code.  
- Drop it off within 30 days of delivery to keep full-refund eligibility.

If you’d like, I can also help you track the return using that RMA once you’ve dropped it off.</action>
